description: From French massage (noun), from masser (“to massage”) (borrowed around the end of the 18th century from Arabic مَسَّ‎ (massa, “feel, touch”), or from Portuguese amassar) + -age. Cognate to German massieren.

entries.meaning: The action of rubbing, kneading or hitting someone's body, to help the person relax, prepare for muscular action (as in contact sports) or to relieve aches.
examples: Having a massage can have many beneficial effects.

verbs.description: massage (third-person singular simple present massages, present participle massaging, simple past and past participle massaged)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To rub and knead (someone's body or a part of a body), to perform a massage on (somebody).
examples: So after massaging a nude woman while being nude or nearly nude myself, sex is a natural way to end things.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To manipulate (data, a document etc.) to make it more presentable or more convenient to work with.
examples: News relating to public disturbances was systematically massaged [...].
